title: Casarecce die for Marcato Atlas Regina pasta extruder

description.text:
A die for your Marcato/Atlas/Regina cheapo home pasta extruder.  Seems to work well.  Printed in PLA 100% fill and 0.2mm layers for strength.  
May revise to make ports a little farther apart - and maybe lose one.  Pasta comes out pretty close to each other, and sticking is a problem.  
The extruder is a pretty inexpensive one - about $80 or so on Amazon.  Its a bit of work to use, but worth the low $$  
Update 6/8/15 - added v2 of die with 5 thicker ports.

author: moomaker4ever

description.text:
A 6 inch square blinky light project using a 25 strand of 2801 pixels, an HC-SR04 ultrasound distance sensor, a teensy, and 3d printed parts. There's a brief video showing the lights blinking here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QLblRXmSe3s

I find the the 5x5-lenses file looks best when printed in white PLA. For the other pieces, color doesn't matter much since it's going to pretty much disappear when it's dark out and the panel is on. You'll need one back, 4 corners, 4 sides, 1 backing LED mount, and one lens. I assembled them with super glue and used a pair of trauma shears to cut slots in the back for my wiring. For the ultrasonic distance sensor I just found a mount I liked somewhere and glued the whole thing to the top. The electronics are pretty simple, I'm running a teensy 2.0 with the arduino code over here:
https://github.com/bobiam/_5x5_ultra You need a separate power line for the LEDs and the teensy, and a few wires from teensy to the sensor and teensy to the strip. If you're interested in building this, there's a wiring sketch in the photos and I'm happy to respond to any questions in the comments.

There are lots of Thingiverse objects to help with the problem of getting all the toothpaste out of a tube.  This design is simpler than anything I have seen.  It should print easily on any printer, cleans up readily, and works simply and well.  The design is clean and unobtrusive.

• Print the squeezer. Clean up and sand as needed (very easy on this simple, flat object).

  • Flatten the end of the toothpaste tube a bit, then stick the end through the narrow slot in the squeezer. This may take a bit of wiggling depending on the tube.

  • Pull the squeezer towards the full end of the tube as far as possible. Continue to advance the squeezer over time as you empty the tube, ensuring that all the contents are used.

If you use the workaround to print with bulk filament instead of the crazy expensive Cube filament you may notice all of the pulling a shoving the carts in and out start to ware on the printer and the chip contacts.   
You can open up a cart and remove the chip on the bottom and glue it onto this. This way you can gently set the chip on the contacts and remove it once the print starts without wearing down the contacts.  
Use print pad glue and slide it into the raised square space on the stick. You can use the open square to easily put it on and off of the contacts.

author: gmckee13

description.text: This tiny item fits snugly into the end of 1/4" irrigation tubing, and splits the stream in two.  My intent was to reduce the speed of the water as it exited, and also spread out the area where water is directed.  It prints with the holes at the top, and doesn't need any support.  It's quite small, so if you have problems with bed adhesion you might need to add a raft.  I printed about half a dozen in white PLA with no issues.  My water is delivered through a siphon, so there is almost no pressure; this item is best suited for a low-pressure drip-type system, not directly off of a city water line.
Printed in white PLA at 230 degrees, sticking to painters tape on an unheated bed.  I printed at 100% fill because I wanted it to be water-tight.

description.text:
Merci de lire l'avertissement en cliquant sur le profil.
Imaginé et développé par les étudiants ergothérapeutes de 3ème année de l'IUFE d'Auvergne (promo 2015), cette cale est étudiée pour faciliter l'application de dentifrice sans avoir à tenir la brosse à dent. Le profil de la cale permet également aux personnes déficientes visuelles d'avoir un retour tactile sur l'emplacement de la brosse. Thanks to read warnings by clicking profil.
Imagined et developped by the occupationals therapyst student from the IUFE of Auvergne (class 2015), this wedge is studied to facilitate applying of toothpaste without the need of holding the tootbrush.
The wedge profil also allows people with visual impairment to get a tactile feedback of the brush position.

title: DC-DC Adjustable Voltage Converter Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This case will enclose a DC-DC adjustable converter. It exposes a knob that friction fits over the screw of the board mounted pot and is held in place by the enclosure. It exposes the connectors for the power in and power out for easy prototyping without exposing the guts to accidental touching.
The one I printed I acetone finished for the glossy look. If you find my designs useful, please help by donating.

This should be printable without scaffolding.
The design of the top has holes large enough for heat press nuts, make sure to get ones that fit the screws that you have. The protrusions that will hold the nut will deform as the heated nut is inserted to become round as pictured; but are printed square.
The knob hole will need to be drilled out to a tight fit for the potentiometer screw. If you drill out too large, you will then need to slit the knob (a slot is designed in) to insert a needle and secure a needle across the hole. Then just make sure the needle is slotted into the screw as you assemble. In my case, this was not needed as the friction was good.
If you finish the print, you may need to sand a few spots as the print has tight tolerances. I had to sand the lower knob hole just a minor amount and the bottom of the knob for the perfect fit.

A cheap 3-way valve becomes much more useful when it is actuated by a servo! Use this as part of an elaborate aquarium air system, a component in an automatic watering scheme, or to switch intake/outlet for a syringe pump (like this Thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:866904). Thanks to Nordson Medical for the samples to develop this! Still in progress since the spacing for the raw valve and the cover are not quite right. But you can file it to fit.

Print one of each part. It's a good idea to test fit things and trim or file to fit. I had to trim a bit off the corners of one of the mounting brackets on my servo, and had to file a bit to make the little valve fit when I put the cover on it.
Hardware:
1 three-way valve. I used Nordson Medical FCLBFFM-1A-003. They were good enough to send me a sample, but I haven't found a source for these where I could order less than 100. If you know of such a place, please post. Similar three-way valves will likely work.
1 servo with fittings. Use whatever horn allows you to screw on the Valve Drive.
3 10mm (min) x M3 screws to hold the Valve Body Case and the Valve Servo Case together.
2 10mm x M3 screws to hold the Valve Cover on.
2 10mm (min) x M4 screws to hold the servo in.
2 M4 nuts. Assembly: Use an M3 tap to tap the holes in the Valve Body Case for the Valve Cover and the holes in the Valve Servo Body for the Valve Body Case.
  • Align the servo so it is centered (at 90 degrees).
  • Screw the Valve Drive to the Servo horn so the valve handle fits into the Valve Drive when the handle is centered. The handle should be a snug slip fit.
  • Slip the valve into place on the Valve Body Case with the handle centered. Put the Valve Cover on and secure it.
  • Mount the servo into the Valve Servo body.
  • Put the Valve Body Case into place with the valve handle in the Valve Drive.
    • Have fun with your new valve!

comments.text: The specific valve I used is Nordson Medical (nordsonmedical.com) FCLBFFM-1A-003. They were kind enough to send me samples. The valve is typical of ones used in medical facilities all over. I've seen them used often in intravenous infusion connections.

author: tmash

title: Bahtnikov Mask for Celestron Sky Prodigy 130 or NexStar 130

description.text:
Bahtnikov Mask for Celestron Sky Prodigy 130 or NexStar 130.
I used http://astrojargon.net/maskgenerator.aspx to calculate the optimal dimensions and drew this up in DesignSpark Mechanical. Should be appropriate for any 650mm focal length newtonian with a 150mm opening.

I printed this in black ABS with 0.2mm layer height, one shell, 100% infill. Depending on your slicer and nozzle size, you may have trouble getting the 2.2mm wide slats to print solid. Simplify3D with a 0.4mm nozzle did not want to print infill with 2 shells.  
To finish, just add a few bits of self adhesive velcro (the soft side) to the tabs to make sure it sits snug in the scope, without flexing.

This mount allows you to put 80/20 1010 extrusion into the mount. I am using it to make a spool holder. Plus, having T slot on the printer gives me options for mounting more stuff. I tweaked the Thing 770657 to make it fit the 1010 extrusion. Check his out if you like pipe for the mount. I am using this with my 8020 braces and filament holder found here: Braces
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:868136 Filament holder
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:868784

For mounting a 1kg filament spool from Hatchbox, I cut two 7" extrusions from 8020 [the 1010 size]
I then cut a 5 1/8" center top piece to go between the two vertical pieces.
I printed out some custom braces [coming soon] and a customized spool holder that mounts directly to the horizontal extrusion. I will add the files once I verify everything is good.

description.text: This is a basic cover for the atx power supply void. Just pick honeycomb pattern as fill. 20%fill.

This is a remix that replaces the sliding jaw with one that accommodates the placing of a billiard cue. Similar to a q claw but utilizes clamps instead of weight. There are two versions, a single cue clamp and a triple cue clamp. Both share the same bar and lock. With the triple cue clamp you can use either one or two bars, but I find two bars are the most stable. Both would probably benefit from a piece of rubber stuck to the jaws or dipped in plastidip.
This is a relatively small cup with the Batman symbol engraved onto the outer face of the object!

This thing was created using Autodesk Inventor entirely to create the file so it will have the dimensions that it needed to have. Once the file has been constructed, I used MakerBot's "The Replicator" for the printing process. The object is 2 in by 2 in and the MakerBot was using blue filament. The whole process took around an hour to be created.

title: Extruder for Prusa i3 Rework, Groove plate and j-head 3mm mount

description.text:
Quick and dirty modification of the standard i3 rework extruder STL to use an aluminum groove plate mount for a much more rigid hotend assembly.   
Created because the previous extruder I used started to soften where the hotend connects to the body, causing it to deviate from vertical.  
Also includes mounting holes on the side using the same 30mm spacing of the wade extruder for the standard i3, that means you can reuse fan ducts designed for it. Those holes go through so you can mount things on both sides.  
An adapter is provided to reuse i3 Rework fan ducts.
Use M5 nuts&bolts to attach the groove plate to the extruder body.

description.text: They're small black lo-res ABS prints, but they will be part of China Blue's upcoming Firefly Projects (http://www.chinablueart.com/FireflyProjects.html) show at the Newport Art Museum (http://www.newportartmuseum.org/pages/upcoming_exhibitions.cfm)in Newport, RI. So now Makerbot Cupcake now makes museum-grade prints. Backstory: China Blue needed clips to hold the LEDs and leads connected to the controlling arduino for her firefly tree, so asked if I could print 100 or so of them with the wings at different angles, so I made a batch of 4 with different wing positions (FFangledclipChinaBlue.stl). Then she wanted different decorative fireflies for her solar-charged FireFly Book, so Bookfireflies.stl has another group of 4 small bug shaped prints.

Clips and bugs created with Rhino3D v4.0, saved as .stl files.  G code parameters to print work best with 0.1 infill solidity, everything else as default for a MK4 cupcake printer with no heated bed in ReplicatorG24.  There are quite a few threads but the objects are solid, so they clean up fine.

This is a simple, cheap and flexible modular model rocket design in OpenSCAD. Using Customizer you can:
  • Select a rocket size (e.g. mini, standard, C)
  • Choose how many fins and what size
  • Vary the height of the various sections (finCan, body, nose cone, etc)
  • Alter the type of nose cone
  • Add an optional, payload section
  • Set your guide rod size
  • Tweak the tolerances for your printer
    • Make sure to customize and export the various parts, then get printing. The rockets are fairly durable, even without a recovery system, but the heat from the rocket engines mean the finCan will only last a few flights (if using PLA). Nonetheless, this is a very fast/cheap way to play with different model rocket designs and great fun with kids - especially as they can design their own rockets. I'd recommend tweaking the Perimeter value to generate 2 perimeters in your slicer (probably around 1mm) - one perimeter just melts too quickly. Here's a video of some of these flying - we were running late to the field, so didn't have time to add drogues/parachutes, but they are highly recommended: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0j5vvKFOFlI&feature=youtu.be The OpenSCAD should be a good starting point if you want to design your own sections for the rocket, or add different nose cones, fin types, etc.

• Support for swept back fins and automatic print support for rocket body
  • Improved coupling joints (lighter, sprung fit)
  • Fins can now be twisted to rotate the rocket in flight (for stability)
  • Option of a shockcord fixing at the base of the payload coupling
  • Added Haack nose cone type (constant be varied for LV, LD or anything in between)
  • Fins tips can now be offset vertically
  • Added support for guide rails (rail buttons) as well as guide rods
  • Added payload bulkhead option
  • Fixed STL generation bug for nose cone
  • Added additional fin and nose cone shapes
  • Added option to generate complete rocket as single STL (without internal couplers, etc)

1) Customise, download and print the various parts for your model - 0.3mm layers is fine. Try to avoid using a brim - it's a pain to remove without cracking the thin-walled parts.
2) Fit a recovery chute/drogue (if desired) and associated wadding
3) Install a suitable rocket engine - start with something low powered (Estes A or B) - you may need a bit of tape around the engine to get a snug fit.
4) Install igniter, place on launch stand, countdown, FIRE!

comments.text:
Absolutely brilliant and exactly what I was looking for. I found that my OpenScad version (2014.01) was inadequate - updating to 2015.03-1 was well worth it as it offers quite a few new features.

The only problem I've had is that printing the fins from a relatively small tip doesn't work - there is just not enough adhesion to keep the very small segment of layer 1 plastic in contact with the printing bed, and inevitably one of them lifts off before I've built up enough fin to connect to the can. I'm experimenting with a flat trailing edge which I don't think makes much difference in subsonic flight profiles - see https://www.apogeerockets.com/technical_publication_16

So I set fin_tip_flat_base to 36 (fin_width - a very small amount) and this should print much more easily and should fly just as well...

I appreciate how much time it makes to properly do a parametric modeller and share it rather than just sharing some stl files, and this is truly impressive! Thank you for sharing!

description.text: This is a gift that I made for my mom for Mother's Day. It was quick and easy and also fun to make.

First, I made a file on Adobe Illustrator and created the Ms and the O. I made the document 10 inches by 9 inches. Then I measured three pieces of plywood that matched my document. After they were cut, I went to my printing preferences. I set the Job Type settings to Vector and clicked the Auto Focus box. My vector settings were the following:
-Speed: 14
-Power: 100
-Frequency: 5000
Lastly, I printed and found pictures that I made all black and white (using iPiccy.com) and used Mod Podge to glue onto the wood. For the finishing touch I wrote my mom a letter on the "O" and gave it to her for Mother's Day.

This item isn't complete yet.

• 23th June: Updated the parts and removed outdated ones. Should be fairly complete and functional now. Requires testing.
  • 10th June: The parts are approaching final completion. I am however experiencing problems with the wristband. Either it's printed in one piece - with the effect that the end connectors aren't holding strong enough. Or I print it one by one and assemble it afterwards. Yet, it's not as strong holding as it needs to be. On the bright side, the screen buttons are now working really well and the battery case is also looking nice as well as being functional.

title: Bob Beck blood purifier casing with adjustable electrode sliders

description.text:
For those of you who are not familiar with this device checkout http://bobbeck.com/ Unaccepted by regular medical sciences but has cured so may people. This casing is for one of the devices of the Bob Beck protocol, the blood purifier. For good results please use the whole protocol and not only this device. The electronics involved are expanded with a little voltage trippler which makes it possible to use one 9 volt battery. This design has the cheapest method for adding cotton to the electrodes by using simple cotton buds. You can slide the electrodes for the right position to the blood vessels at your wrists.
This casing is open source, make it better at https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jBFEB7weoKd-bob-beck-blood-purifier-complete-casing

Layer height for 3D printing is 0.2mm. You may use ABS or PLA it makes not really much difference for these objects. It is important to make the cotton buds wet with water which has salt in it. This is necessary to make the conductance the best for the pulsing trough your skin to the blood vessels otherwise it seems like the pulsing does not work at all. Start the first day with 8 minutes and every next day 8 minutes longer until you reach 2 hours a day for 2 months. Again please read and use the whole protocol from Bob to clean your blood and take back your power!.

Or view some testimonials over here which are blowing me away again and again. http://www.bobbeck.com/Testimonial_search.aspx

This is a remix of the Bicycle Cup Holder on this site. The original circle  wasn't large enough for my mug, so I split it from the handlebar holder and modeled a new circle. The interior diameter of this circle is 3" and it's straight, not angled like the original. No supports are needed for printing.  
You'll need to clean out and slightly enlarge the screw holes with a bit of drilling afterwards.

comments.text: Good, easily printable design.  One suggestion, however.  The cupholder part of this design is basically a straight cylinder, which means it only works with tapered cups/bottles.  If the cupholder itself tapered inwards a bit, it would work with a wider variety of containers.
comments.author: aroth

comments.text: Made this and the part that is supposed to fit around the bike handlebars is way too big, even for a mountain bike.  Most bike handlebars are between 0.75" to 1" diameter while this is closer to 1.25".  Even with a piece of rubber, the diameter is too big and I ended up breaking the piece trying to flex it smaller.  I have remixed this to decrease the diameter of the handlebar mount portion.  Thanks!
comments.author: amcbride

comments.text: I also noticed that the bottom (or top depending on orientation) wasn't flat so it the first layer would print weird.  It had problems sticking to the bed w/ higher temp filament so I evened out that surface.

title: Airsoft GBB Magazine Dry Fire Adapter

description.text:
This will hold your magazine follower down, allowing you to fire a GBB pistol (or rifle) with gas but no BBs. Great for training or having fun without putting dents in the walls.  
The design has been revised since Thingiverse removed the original file (politics below). It now sits even more securely on the follower now I understand almost all double stack followers slope in the same direction.  
The main picture is from SirLanceOlong's make of my original file. I would ask him if he minds me using his picture but he is no longer registered on Thingiverse, hopefully he will get in contact if he objects.  
Thingiverse took this Thing down citing copyright infringement on behalf of Glock. Glock does not produce airsoft parts, and certainly does not make one of these magazine follower stops. This is my own design (obviously) and I believe the infringement claim was made by a malicious third party. This seems to have affected at least 4 other users on Thingiverse that I can see, none of which I can tell had infringed on any product that Glock make (most of which I am quite familiar with). Thingiverse/Makerbot have yet to respond to any of my emails after a week (now 2 months) so I am reposting this Thing for the benefit of all.

This tiny piece of plastic is a stupidly quick print, and incredibly useful.   
In order to make the most of all the super tiny features and angles I've printed the black one you see in the gallery at 0.05mm (!) layer height. No supports, most slicers will give this 100% infill due to the size. I really recommend using glue and low bed temps to minimise warping of the very tiny features.

comments.text: Wont dry firing dammage the gun?
comments.author: MattyAnder

comments.text: Absolutely not, as long as you have gas in it. Most will be OK even without gas.
comments.author: MattyAnder

title: OBSOLETE: Geared extruder with bsp fitting for flexible filament

description.text: OBSOLETE! Superseded by this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:933829

This is the cross-mix of the Geared Extruder by terenceang (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:456095) and my own direct drive extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:859583, which is in turn a derivative from well-known Airtripper BSP v3 extruder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:126778). Update (June 08, 2015): Made wider holes for Allen bolt heads, uploaded DS Mechanical source file for the extruder, enjoy! With MK8 gear and 1/4 microstepping you'll need approximately 150 steps per millimeter. Update (June 29, 2015): Added updated files to address minor issues found with the initial version, not tested yet.

title: Mounting Bracket for Three 3.5-Inch Drives in Two 5.25-Inch Drive Bays

description.text:
I have a rackmount server with a drive cage for one 3.5" hard drive and three 5.25" drives, but I wanted to mount four 3.5" drives.
This bracket adapts 3.5" drives to fit in the 5.25" cage and positions three 3.5" drives vertically in the space intended for two 5.25" drives.

If desired, edit the OpenSCAD to select whether or not to make relief cuts for better screw hole perimeters ("relief" variable, default true) using Zach's incomplete polygon method from http://blog.makerbot.com/2010/12/13/design-tip-incomplete-polygons/ . The code is fully parametric but you're unlikely to want to change much else besides screw sizes and minimum plastic thickness. Print four brackets. I had good luck with the heated build platform on my CupCake, and you will need most of your X-axis travel. Remove any ooze and stringing from the small-drive mounting ridges. Drill through the supporting membrane under the six upper holes with a 9/64" or comparable bit. Clean out the four lower pilot holes if needed. Set three 3.5" hard drives on edge, set two brackets onto them with the mounting holes aligned and the bulk of the bracket body toward the center of the drives (screw recesses toward the ends), and install the drive-mounting screws. Flip the assembly and repeat for the other two brackets. Position the whole assembly inside the drive cage, aligning the pilot holes with the cage's mounting holes, and mount to the cage. Sheet-metal screws worked best to self-tap the plastic pilot holes.

comments.text: I have a lot of hard drives mounted this way, but I do have fans blowing straight through them. They have survived for years this way, so adequate cooling can be accomplished.

title: Snap and Load Weedeater blades (for Weed Warrior)

description.text: I ran out of blades for my weed eater and I was about to head to home depor and grab some, but it struck me...I CAN PRINT THAT! made in tinkercad using the original blade as a base and took some liberties with my take on what would work well for cutting grass. printed in PET at 100% infill. my test blade fit perfect and lasted a good while before I hit the house and sheared it off. it was only 20% infill though. I am thinking 100% can get me through a yard. Will update next weekend when I have to mow again :D Just to be safe - do this at your own risk. completely untested and I don't exactly think stuff through all the way before I do it. Mainly an exercise to see if i could do it. First results are in...as a proof of concept it works. not very practical and definitely not safe. fun to play with though. I may try some other designs that may be more sturdy https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uXjaNJJvpWw http://imgur.com/VR4UNVf

comments.text: I printed this in ABS with 50% hexagon infill.  I can run the blades up against wood, stone or concrete and they just grind or chip away instead of snapping.  These last twice as long as the store bought and they cut better.

title: Wanhao Duplicator I3 Filament Tube holder

description.text: This thing holds the end of a 4mm O.D. 2mm I.D. filament tube on the top left corner of the frame using the existing two holes in the frame. There is a slit in the top that allows you to remove the tube and filament without having to pull the filament out first. Here is a link to a video showing me install and remove the tube with filament already installed. https://youtu.be/kvME-4vNJ0M

Requires two M3 16mm screws as the original would be two short. Print and screw in on the top left corner of the printer where the two existing screws are. Insert the end of a section of 4mm OD, 2mm ID PTFE tubing. I am using a piece about 700mm long but a shorter piece could be used. Mine has a natural curl in it that seems to work out nicely. The other end will seat on top of the extruder. This keeps any movement of the extruder from pulling the filament and possibly pulling on the extruder and causing small defects in the print. https://youtu.be/kvME-4vNJ0M

comments.text: What tube did you use?
comments.author: sebastianheyn

comments.text: What is the benefit of running this tube?  Does the end end at the extruder side get clamped into the extruder by using the hand lever on it?
comments.author: gearmesh

comments.text: It keeps the filament from jerking the extruder and causing variations in the print or nozzle to bed height. The tube above the extruder leaver just sits there. The action of the filament being pulled in always keeps the tube in place.
comments.author: gearmesh

comments.text: Thanks for this. I may end up using it. My larger concern is securing the end of the tubing that presses against the extruder. If left unconstrained it sometimes bends at odd angles and may cause a lot of friction. Any ideas?

comments.text: Ok im still new to the 3d printing scene. So when you say keep it .6mm thick, I should print 2 shells of .3mm? Can vase mode be used to print this off?
comments.author: woodknack

comments.text: I'm assuming vase mode is some type of hollowing out aspect.  There are a lot of various terms for this.  But yes you're on the right track. Most printers will only go down to .3mm laterally. They can make smaller layers but the nozzle is usually limited to .3mm across.  To print this without support you have to print it vertically. I made the wall thickness .6mm intentionally because I knew it would automatically print 2 shells on most printers.  The concept of this model is that it should be as light as possible. So you want that middle part to be as thin as possible. That's all I was trying to do. 1 shell is too brittle and 2 seems pretty good though. I hope this helps.

• Made for the FolgerTech variant of the Prusa I3 but I'm sure it can be used for most Prusas
  • Two mounting holes are 3.25mm and are 20mm apart from center
  • Mounting clips are based off two 8mm linear rods that or 45mm apart from center or 37mm apart from the edge.
  • Only use if you have the same end stop shown in my picture.
Mount the commonly used end stop that comes with most repraps on the mount 20 2 m3 bolts and snap it on to the linear rods.

Still exploring the possibilities of modifying a 2D primitive while extruding it. Added rotation in any axis to the previous scaling, which required adjusting the extrusion thickness to make sure the layers met.
The layers are 1/4 mm thick.

It took 5 hours on this recentish latop to render the STL, but you can probably live with thicker layers, which would render faster. Skeinforge sliced it with no problems. Play with the OpenSCAD script, or print the STLs directly. GitHub repository:
github.com/syvwlch/Thingiverse-Projects/tree/master/ScaleExtrudeHorns

description.text: If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays It's just a sphere, the sort of thing that shouldn't print without supports, so you can test supports. This is the sort of shape that no matter what I try does not print well. If anyone can give me some pointers how to make this work I would be so grateful. In the picture on the left is a sphere I started printing without supports accidentally, and on the right is the sphere and the supports that printed it. Sadly, there's very little difference between the two even after adjusting the settings according to /thing:41467 and lowering the minimum angle to 30 (which didn't work the way I expected it to).

comments.text: I know this is a bit of an old thread, but I wanted to put a note here for anyone else trying this.  It is possible to get a pretty good print, but this is a very hard object.  It has multiple issues.  It is a small object with severe overhang that is on a curve.  I was able to print pretty severe overhangs, but doing so with small parts and curving overhangs is a whole different thing.  The main solution for me was two-fold.  First, I needed to drop the acceleration down a bit.  Accelerations that worked for all other prints had issues with this part.  I didn't need to go terribly low (1000mm/s^2) just lower than normal.  I also turned on a cooling fan after the first few layers, but only at about 12% power.  I needed a PWM to analog voltage circuit to make that possible.  Generally, cooling is bad with ABS, so this is a balancing act.  I also lifted the part a bit off the bed so that the support goes completely under the part.  You can see the results in the "I made one" section.
comments.author: orgemd

comments.text: I have found that "bowl-shaped" things benefit a lot from a cooling fan directed at the nozzle exit point.  It seems that the hot plastic just wants to curl inward with those shapes, and cooling it quickly appears to help.  Also, I am using Slic3r and noticed one of its most recent versions doesn't respond correctly to support angle parameters.  But it looks like you are using Makerware, so that shouldn't be your problem.

description.text:
Basically it’s just a cup and handle for a giant slingshot.
It’s my dog’s absolute favorite toy. Whenever she wants to play she takes her ball and sits underneath it until I get the hint. You’ll need elastic and rope to put it together, and a couple of trees or posts to wrap the ropes around. This is the elastic I use:
http://smile.amazon.com/Thera-Band-Exercise-Dispenser-25-Feet-Special/dp/B00066D654/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1433641132&sr=8-3&keywords=theraband+tubing
I get the medium/green. Anything heavier will take more strength to pull back, but should launch it a lot farther. Thread the elastic through the holes in the cup, then tie each end to a piece of rope. (I use zip ties to make sure the elastic doesn’t slip free.) Then wrap the rope around whatever comes to hand.
You’ll need another smaller rope to attach the handle. Just thread it though the holes and tie off each end. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3QL0OLnhLaI

title: Customizable Board Game Storage with Label and Inclination

description.text:
This thing's intend is to keep board game cards in order during play and to store them safely the rest of the time.  
The holder can be completely customized to fit stacks of cards of any dimension. Multiple holders can be stacked safely by using the build in rails.  
Added the option for a custom label on the side of the holder.  
Added the option for a custom Inclination of the holder. The intend is to stack cards sideways, in such angle that it fits the box (I have this problem with Agricola game cards, where storing them sideways, they will overflow the box). Additional feature is that inclined holders are easier to draw cards from, and look cooler. A draw back is that, depending on your parameters, the holder may have odd balance and it does not optimise space.

be careful with your angle:
  • 0=no inclination (same as original works)
  • 90= will break model

  • 30 depending on your printing skills, you may need to add support structures

comments.text: Awesome idea!

title: 2.5" Deck Ledger Board to House Spacer with 0.5" Hole

description.text:
This is a deck spacer to put in-between your house and ledger board to stop water going from the ledger board into your house framing. (same kind of thing you can buy at the home depot for about $3-$5 each)
I suggest a 90% fill to avoid problems while printing. (100% fill was a bit hit and miss to do but is possible)
I printed mine directly on my heated plate with no raft but you must have your plate very level to pull that off so level it before you begin.
Please be aware I'm not a structural engineer and these may not be strong enough for all i know so print and use these at your own risk. Only print them out of ABS as PLA may biodegrade outside.

This is an flanged ball bearing holder for UBC6000Z (10mm inner ring, 26mm outer diameter and 8mm thickness, http://www.dealextreme.com/p/ubc-6000-2z-precision-steel-bearing-inner-ring-1cm-21666) and 3 x M3 socket cap screw housings (bearing fastening and holder fixation).

You will need some sandpaper work to bring material excess to minimum (due to precise holder dimensions and printing distortion by over temperature or material caracteristiscs). All the M3 socket caps screws housing must be aliviated for easy fastening. Pay attention to one side of bearing fastening (opposite side of the screw cap housing) that need to be tapped/threaded for M3 bolting (or you would put an M3 nut after drilling through that hole). Recommended M3 bolt length: 25mm, http://www.mcmaster.com/#socket-head-cap-screws (or 30mm if you intend to use a nut, http://www.mcmaster.com/#hex-nuts). Preferably printed on MakerBot ThingOMatic with stepstruder MK6 (or you will need some very trickly adjustments, mainly to oozebane the profile).

title: 1in base Tensionable Soft Jaw Vice for Desktop CNC

description.text:
Tensionable Table vice for 1x1 inch grid #6 hole mountingboard.  
Designed to compliment the Modular Table Vice designed by SchmidtN, can be used alongside his device as they provide the same part offset and spacing options.  
This vice adds the ability to tension the vice after it has been installed.  
This design allows for a high holding force with these vices without the use of additional clamps or fasteners.  
The device is designed to be held onto a 1" x 1" grid of #6 holes.  The tensioner slide is secured using a 3/4" #10 screw and nut combo.

Print one of the Vice and optionally one of the Slide. The vice will function without the slide. You will also need 2 #6 screws for fastening down the vice and one 3/4" #10 screw+nut combo for securing the optional slide. I used ABS due to its flexibility though PLA should work the same, just be more brittle overall. 0.2mm Layer Height
Use a high infill for strength. The two pieces are assembled together with a single #10 screw and nut combo. The nut is nested within the printed slot, it should be a snug fit, so if it doesn't immediately drop down you can press it in with a screwdriver. Press the slide into the alignment grooves with the hole facing the screw so that the #10 screw will bite into the slide and help secure it in place.

comments.text: great design but what if you if you design the track of it so that the rail rides in the vice using like a dove tail design
comments.author: valic007

comments.text: I considered a dovetail design but the tail feature would be too thin and small unless I increased the thickness of the base plate.   Since I was trying to keep this low profile I decided to stick with a straight rail.   Also with the uneven torque that will be applied I was concerned the dovetail would seize in its track and crack.

title: Cheap multimeter holder (model UT10A)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I like this little cheapo meter for quick stuff, so I made a case for it so it can sit on my oscilloscope. Also, my oscilloscope is an old analog one, so to give me basic numerical measurements, I hacked an interface to the cheapo meter. I have BNC T connectors on each input, with one line of BNC cable going to clips taken out of a busted breadboard. The clips get soldered to a bit of wood. This lets me snap the probes of the meter into whatever the oscilloscope is probing. Of course, this is horrible for high frequency stuff, so I unplug it for anything delicate, but it's fine for getting a running amplitude measurement of a simple AC signal, and it's a lot cheaper than getting a digital scope...
Print, then tape or screw holder into some surface.

author: HAAUK

description.text: Mount to extend the Printrboard USB port and mount it on the 3uP frame when using a Micro USB male to female adapter cord extension angle connecter. This mount is sized to match the 3uP Power Switch mount, and can be used with the modified Printrboard Mount to set the Printboard edge back from the frame edge, so that the USB plug does not extend past the frame edge.

The OpenSCAD model can be resized for different plug sizes. Check your USB plug sizing, and adjust the model if needed. The model adds 1mm to the width and height of the plug body opening to account for material shrinkage.  
Ream out the M5 hole with a 13/64" drill bit. File the extrusion slot rib to fit snugly, if necessary.  
Glue the plug end flush with the front opening. Some CA glue works fine. A strip of masking tape over the front edge opening will help hold the plug in place and ensure it's flush while the glue dries.

author: tmash

description.text: Printrboard mount for the 3uP that offsets the board away from the edge of the frame to allow clearance for USB extension used with the 3uP USB Port Mount. This also adds provisions to support the mount with two Misumi HBLFSNF5 brackets, which greatly increases the strength and rigidity of the mount.

Ream out the M5 holes with a 13/64" drill bit. Similarly, ream out the M3 holes with a 1/8" drill bit. Insert the M5 and M3 nuts into the mount. It may be necessary to heat-emboss the nuts into the plastic. A soldering iron tip should fit into the nut opening and allow the nut to be heated while pressing it into the mount. Don't drive the nuts in too deeply, or plastic will get into the nut threads and ruin them! The nuts at the edge of the mount for the 3uP Wire Bundler are optional. Attach the HBLFSNF5 brackets to the mount, and to the extrusion frame using M5 screws, and T-nuts in the extrusion. Use another two M5 screws and T-nuts to attach the mount along the front edge as well. Finally, attach the Printrboard to the mount with four M3 screws.

Since creating my webcam mount ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8618 ) for my RapMan I obviously needed some cool capturing software too. Being a .NET programmer I wanted to write something as I could put features in which I wanted. Instead of re-inventing the wheel I searched the web for C# source code to use to grab images from the webcam. I came across something that already had about 90% of the functionality I wanted. I found WCamTimeLaps by ShoXDK on Codeplex @ http://wcamtimelapse.codeplex.com I made a few small mods like saving the settings to an application config file. I also added FTP functionality to upload images to my web site (temp location for now). It's a pretty simple application. You set the delay time between each picture, default is 1000 ms (1 sec). You can set a start time and/or end time when capturing must happen after Start it pressed or it will just capture indefinitely until Stop is pressed. In the Config file I put a setting called NthFrameToUpload meaning every nth image i.e. every 30th image will be uploaded. You can change the ftp server address from the interface but I must still add text boxes for the folder on the FTP site (FTP_Folder), the FTP user ID (FTP_UID) and the FTP password (FTP_PWD). When uploading the app will check on the FTP folder for the OutputFileName i.e. print_image.jpg and rename it to old_print_image.jpg, upload the new image as new_print_image.jpg and once uploaded rename it to print_image.jpg As the application's name suggest you can also create time-lapse videos. This program will not make the video file for you, it will only taken the images, but you can use virtualdub (http://virtualdub.sourceforge.net/) to make it into a movie clip (see http://diy.wikia.com/wiki/Time_Lapse_Photography). I then wrote an ASP.NET page to show off my printing. This page uses an AJAX UpdatePanel which updates every 30 seconds to load the latest uploaded print image. I still need to change the process to show some other generic image or message when there is no "current" print job running. I will also be uploading all the time-lapse video I'll be making from the print jobs...possibly to YouTube also. One important aspect I must look at is the lighting on the print job. For my first "official" run I set up temp lighting which is not up to the level that I want. [EDIT] - 2011-05-30 - At the moment I am haing some stability issues egarding uploading of images. My FTP seems to timeout too easily causing the upload to fail in total although the time-lapse capturing continues successfully. I have implemented a web-service to which I upload the images but came across an unhandled exception which I have not yet had the time to resolve.

View my printing at http://www.neophytewebs.co.za/3dprint.aspx Check back often for print jobs running as I do a lot of printing and there will be something running every day. [EDIT] - I forgot to mention: You need .NET Framework 3.5 for this to work correctly. It was developed on Windows 7 - x64 and also tested and running on Windows XP. When reporting any errors...please also state at what point it occurs to help me with troubleshooting and error handling.

title: Dial Indicator Replicator 2X
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a tool for the Replicator 2x.
You use it with a Dial Indicator, I used a analog one.
When you shall use it then you must start the leveling script on the replicator in the menu. Then cancel it after the first position.
Then you got the build plate up and you can start measure the built plate.
You need to calibrate it at the height you want it to be.
The easy way is to measure the nozzle height in one spot that you want, like 0.1mm and then move the dial indicator to that spot, then zero it.
Now you have it calibrated and you can use the Jog function in the menu and move it all around the build plate and measure. Start with the positions you have the screws.
Go over the built plate a couple of time and you should be okey. P.S if you mirror the object you can put it on the other side to. The STL is only for the right side of the extruder/nozzle.

I made this with 123D Design. Make the part with 4 or more shells and you can have low % of infill.
The critical part is the arm that goes over the fan. If you have more shells it will be more rigid and not break.
I did print this with 10% infill and 4 shells.
Also you need to use support to print this. **** I made version 2 of this. The change is the lower clip is smaller gap in, so it will hook into the carriage better.

description.text:
To rebase or not to rebase...

  • I do not particularly like the look of gluing a smaller base on top of a larger base; even if you add scenic elements to hide the old base, the added height just doesn't look right (not to mention that changes the line of sight by an additional 3.5mm; although cover saves are now shorter by 3.5mm - lol)

  • When you somehow managed to accumulate a bag of 400 or so older 25mm bases around it doesn't hurt to repurpose them to the slightly larger base size as needed - and the fancy, top/front heavy metal models appreciate the more stable base dimensions. These are beveled on the inside to fit the generic/Citadel/GW beveled bases.

  • Print 2x for each base; prints in about 4-8 minutes (depending on which dimension you choose and your printer setting). Prints without support. Fits snuggly around the base of existing model to expand it to 32mm or 40mm. Includes a partially open (hit)marker ring for 25mm bases.

description.text: The Marblatron produces a brilliant pulse of light, signaling the arrival of a metallic ball from the Luminiferous Ether. This ball spirals downward. Mainly this is due to the effects of gravity, amongst other things. Until finally it disappears from whence it came. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5Zvh_fvajl0 The light is generated from a 24 LED Adafruit Neopixel ring. This ring fits neatly in the cap piece, and a ribbon cable runs down through access holes in the riser sections to the base. In the base there is a location for an Arduino Nano that runs the Neopixels and ball sensor. The ball sensor is simply two wires that are at the top of the screw section. These sense when a ball is about to be ejected onto the track as it comes in contact with them. The Arduino then produces a bright pulse of light just before the ball pops out. At other times, the Marblatron simply generates a rotating pulse of yellow light to help gravity do it's work.

Assembly is pretty straight forward. Start out with one "riser" section and go from there. You will need the number of risers +1 "screw" sections and hex connectors. Inside the screw sections, there is a small notch preventing the hex connector from falling down into the hole. This is only on one side of the screw section. This should be towards the top of each screw section. There are three small dimples in the top of each screw section to indicate the side with the internal stops that should be toward the top. A drop a glue here might help also, though was not required to stack four in my case. You will need two "bearing" shafts. Place these on either end of the assembled screw sections. The bottom one (that fits in the gearbox) has the gear inserted on the bearing shaft first, and then fitted into the bottom screw section. The gear teeth should point downwards. The vertical motor gear mates with the horizontal screw gear. You may need to drill out the motor gear slightly to get it on the motor shaft. It is designed to be a tight fit on the shaft. The riser sections, gearbox, and riser top attach together with small tabs. These can be tight enough to break the tabs off when disassembling, so you may prefer to sand them down a little to provide a looser fit. Each riser section requires two sets of rails (4 total). You will also need a couple extra for the ends. The rail sections just snap into the holes in the riser sections. Where two come together, the hole is wide enough to accept the two tabs side-by-side. Each rail has a small female and male tab that align them vertically as well. The female notch should go below the male notch as you work your way up. The male notch in each rail section has a small support built into the model itself. Snap this off prior to assembly so that the rails are flush were they mate together. It can be a bit tricky getting the rails to align. Do not force them too much or they may snap. Non-printed Parts Required:
The design uses the following 6V 30RPM motor from amazon: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B009AQLDSS?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00 For the "marbles", I used 10mm ball bearing from a bicycle shop (amazon is a good source). Also some ribbon cable and headers if using the Neopixels, ball sensor, and Arduino, and a 5V 2amp power supply. Of course the Arduino, Neopixel ring, and ball sensor are all optional, if you don't care for the added effect or added complexity. Arduino:
The marblevator.ino code is attached. For the attached program, the Neopixel ring ties to digital pin 6. The sensor wires connect to digital pin 2 and ground. The Arduino is powered from the 5V supply on pins 29 (gnd) and 30 (Vin). The pull-up is enabled on pin 2, and the ball making electrical contact and pulling pin 2 to ground is what "senses" the ball is present. There aren't any holes in the model for the ball sensor wires. Just drill these to match whatever wire you have laying around. If the wire is thicker, be sure the ball can get up and over it as it comes off the screw. You can test without the top cap in place to ensure things are working. Neopixels are a bit finicky. If using them in your build, I would suggest adding a small capacitor across the motor terminals to avoid the electrical noise that may cause the Neopixels to flicker. My Neopixels flickered quite vigorously without this. Also, be sure to add the capacitor and resistor on the Neopixel ring. Adafruit recommends this (see their website for details). Skipping this can burn out the first Neopixel from the inrush current when plugging in the supply (don't ask me how I know). If you do burn out the first pixel due to your brazen disregard for reading instructions, it will appear the entire ring no longer works. It is just the first Neopixel that is the problem, however. You can de-solder it, and then apply the digital input to the next one in the chain to get the ring going again, albeit with only 23 pixels :(. The whole thing runs on a 5V power supply, and draws about 1 amp maximum with all the pixels and motor running. I would suggest a 5V 2 amp supply just to be safe. Be careful not to plug the Arduino into USB for programming without the power supply plugged in, or you may burn up something, since it will try to source the 1 amp from USB through pins 29 and 30. The printed parts all fit within the 6" x 6" x 6" build volume of my printer (actually a bit smaller), so make sure your printer supports that before starting. I used PLA at 20% infill and fast setting on my printer. I'll add more instructions and assembly pictures soon...

I took the model posted by Wundel (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:69086) and pieced it out into parts that are easier to print. I saw that the only print of this beautiful ship didn't turn out very well, a friend with a printer offered to print it up for me, so I made this in Slic3r, It should allow you to print a much bigger ship than you would otherwise, plus you get to build it as a model kit. I am super excited for getting mine done. Also, I brought the model in as an obj, so the scaling is weird, you will need to scale each part up by 90,000% or to what ever you like before printing. If you import it and don't see anything, it is there, just small. You will need to scale it before you can see it. I hope you enjoy the fruits of my evening. (EDIT:) I finally got an .stl exported, the program I used is a little buggy, so that is the 3rd try. Hope you enjoy it. (EDIT 2) It is now .stl with a bunch of material removed from the middle, I also split things up a little more to make it better for printing. I am super excited to get this printed. I really want to build some LEDs into the inside of it so I can get light shining through the windows.

This two part print will hold and protect a standard MR16 low voltage LED downlight. Note: do not use it with a halogen bulb... It will melt. I used it as a worklight on my Colchester lathe. I purchased cheap LED clamp on type reading light from a well known hardware store but the COB chip in the head of the lamp failed after just a few hours use and since I had modified the flexible stem and switch I couldn't return it. I tried and failed to find a suitable replacement for the LED chip and decided that standard downlight bulbs were easier to replace in the future. The end of the housing has a 12mm diameter socket for fitting over the flexible gooseneck but you can modify the Inventor source file to suit what you have.
I have also included a two part print which allows for a rocker switch to be fitted directly to the stem of the flexible gooseneck. I found a rocker switch in my scrap box which was about the right size so the print was modelled specifically for that switch. I have included the original Inventor parts so you may be able to edit the parts to suit a switch that you might have.

Both parts can be printed without support material by placing the largest diameter face down on the build table. The bulb can be inserted in the housing and the cap is held on with some small self tapping screws.

comments.text:
bbrown1951
In the version I made the lamp connector just sits loose in the top of the lamp body. The front retaining ring does all the work by holding the lamp firmly in the lamp body. I left the wires to the lamp connector long enough so that I could plug in the lamp and then push the excess wire back into the top of the lamp body and then secured the front retaining ring.
comments.author: Preso

comments.text: How is the lamp connector secured inside the housing?
comments.author: bbrown1951

comments.text:
Rollinns,
I purchased my donor lamp from Bunnings here in Australia. Here is the link http://www.bunnings.com.au/verve-5w-led-silver-studio-clip-lamp_p4370829 The lamp came with a spring type clip which I removed. The base of the flexible neck already had a threaded spigot and a nut so I just fitted that through a drilled hole in my lathe cross slide. The lamp also came with an inline switch which I removed. I fitted a rocker switch which I found in my scrap box instead. It is mounted in a printed housing which clamps around the non flexible section of the neck. I will post the parts for this but it was made to suit the switch that I had. If you can edit the parts it can be made to suit any rocker switch. I had to cut a slot in the chrome tubing so that the wires could be routed to the switch. I also had to splice a standard two prong socket at the top for the standard downlight bulb. The lamp already had a really nice chrome lamp head on it but the COB LED failed after a few hours.
comments.author: Preso

It is for ear rings and necklaces.
It is 75mm across (3 inches if you are metric-challenged) and about 12mm deep (about half an inch if you can't do metric).
You put your goodies inside, put the lid on and put a rubber band around it. That's what the ears are for.
It is thin and flat so you can put it in your bag, and stack several of them.
I added a monogram cutout in the lid, but I have removed it from this version. Theoretically you can put anything you want in it, but I have not tested that.

author: arki03

description.text:
An ink guide to be used on an M3D printer to control the travel of your ink.  
Recommended for external ink source.   
No special scaling required. Designed to be the correct size to slot onto the top frame of the printer. May need to adjust orientation depending on your preferred print orientation.

I designed the part on Autodesk 123D Design and exported into Autodesk MeshMixer to check mesh quality for 3D printing.  
Measurements were taken directly from the M3D printer and the print tested. There may be some sanding required on the part that slots on the printer but this depends on how you like your fit i.e. tight or loose.  
Recommend printing at medium quality and medium fill or greater.  
This is version 2 - refinements made on the slot for a filleted edge, to allow for smoother slotting. Decreased width of overall piece and smaller keyhole. Removed element that fixed to outside of printer as this prevented the guide from slotting on. In addition, refinements reduced overall printing time by about half.  
Feedback welcome

title: J Tech Photonics Laser Mount for Mostly Printed CNC
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Turn your Mostly Printed CNC into a Laser Engraver and Cutter.
You can engrave and cut all kind of plastics, light wood, etc. For cutting only thin materials are suitable. When you use this mount, then first adjust the laser as described in the manual and then add the lid. The fan will cool the laser module (important for the life-time) and blow away dust from the lense. First engraving test (and first video i made :P ): [Engraving Wood](https://youtu.be/WM2AMtxMhMk ) Addon: Check out the new version of the lid with two line lasers. The mount was tested with the IE version of the CNC with 25mm conduits. What else do you need?
  • 30mm 12V fan
  • 4x M3x16 bolts for the fan
  • 2x M3x16 bolts to mount the laser module
  • 6x M3 nut
  • 3x M4x16 bolts for the lid
  • 2x M4x20 bolts to tighten the conduit mount
  • 5x M4 nut
    • Safety first!
    When you are using a laser module ALWAYS wear eye protection! Even scattered radioation can make you blind. Your eyes cannot shut quick enough to avoid damage! A laser is no toy so please don't handle it like one. Also be careful with the fume that is generated while engraving. Use a filter with activated carbon or at least keep your windows open.

comments.text: http://jtechphotonics.com/?page_id=3819
comments.author: Allted

comments.text: Hello,
comments.author: S7design

comments.text: Which modified marlin are you using? Also how you generate gcode? Sorry for my questions because I have only experience 3d printing (marlin,Cura...)
comments.author: ase

comments.text: There's no need to modify marlin, the laser works with a "normal" configured 3d printer board with an output for a fan (e.g. D9 on RAMPS). Have a look at this manual, it's very good: http://jtechphotonics.com/?page_id=2012
comments.author: ase

comments.text: Thanks for inkspace plugin that very useful. My TTL driver has arrived. I purchased this http://www.ebay.com/itm/181657463022?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT. On this board there is a TTL input between 0v and 5v. I test it direct ramps 5v and ground connect and adjust laser output 6,5v and 1,6 amps. It works but D9 pin is 12v so I need max 5v for TTL.
comments.author: izytronic

comments.text: Did you finished your engraver?
comments.author: ase

comments.text: How do you control the laser? PWM or on-off  ? I want to know if you use TTL laser controller or not.
comments.author: ase

comments.text:
Currently the control input of my laser module is connected to D9 and can be turned on with gcode M106 and turned off with M107. That works fine for normal engraving or cutting, but controling the laser power is mandatory for engraving pictures with different shades.
I'm working on a TTL solution using one of the servo-ports on the RAMPS board. It will use the M280 gcode. Right now I don't get my laser at full power this way. It seems I need to use the servo-output to control a transistor and supply 12V to the laser module (servo out is only 3.3V or 5V on the pulse wire). Maybe I can give a "go" tomorrow.
comments.author: ase

comments.text: Using D9 for controlling is good but how do you adjust current? I know that the current is important for laser diode life. Also I look forward to your TTL solution. Good work!
comments.author: izytronic

comments.text: Using D9 just let's you turn the laser on or off, so 0% or 100%. Generally the current is adjusted at the laser driver board. This laser module can be operated from 1.3Amps to 2.5Amps - and you're right, 2.5Amps would reduce the lifetime dramatically. So I set the current to 1.8Amps at the moment and I'm using a fan to keep the laser module cool. Cooling is also important for the life-time. There is a input for a control signal (currently on D9), but as I said: only on or off. D9 cannot be used to produce a TTL signal (as far as I know), but the servo-outputs can. It works partly and I can regulate the laser power, but I don't reach the same max. laser power. It could be that the servo-signal-voltage is too low. So I will use this low voltage to control a transistor and can supply a 12V TTL signal to the control input. I hope that fixes my issue.
comments.author: ase

comments.text: D9 is PWM. Example: M106 S127 is 50% on marlin, S can be 0 to 255. Ref: http://reprap.org/wiki/G-code that what i was going to use.
comments.author: izytronic

comments.text:
Hey,
I tried controlling the laser with the M106 command again. I don't know what I did wrong during the first tests, but now it works perfectly.
Using the D9 on the RAMPS board connected directly to the control-input of the J Tech Photonics Bundle works. The laser power can be adjusted with M106 S0 = off to M106 S255 = full power.
comments.author: norm8332

comments.text:
I tried that, but it didn't work. At 0% the laser was off, as far as I remebember anything above 20% turned it on at full power, no way to control the laser power.
And PWM is not the same as TTL. I have to understand to problem myself why controlling the laser is not working, then I can solve it ;)
comments.author: norm8332

comments.text: Videos of something burning! Sorry I can't wait to see this in action! There is another laser setup that just got recommended on the hot end mount page. The other one is cheaper but involves more work. Now I'm torn.
comments.author: Allted

comments.text:
Give me some days for the final setup of my CNC, I'm currently working on an easy way of building large amounts of cable sets (ready to use, without soldering etc.).
I want to whole thing working without using any interim solution :-)
